review.title: Fully Convolutional Architectures for Multi-Class Segmentation in Chest Radiographs
review.abstract: The recent success of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks on image classification and recognition tasks has led to new applications in very diversifying contexts. One of these is medical imaging where scarcity and imbalance of training data has hindered rapid development of neural network related applications.

metadata.title: Fully Convolutional Architectures for Multi-Class Segmentation in Chest Radiographs

sections.text: This paper examines and proposes neural network architectures within the context of automated segmentation of anatomical organs in chest X-ray systems, specifically for lung, collarbone and heart muscle functions. It solves the problem of highly unbalanced target group formation in the input data by modifying objective functionality and trains and tests the models in the publicly available JSRT database, consisting of 247 X-Ray images available in the SCR database. Networks are divided into three target groups; the best models are trained and tested in the publicly available JSRT database, consisting of 247 X-Ray images available in the SCR database.

sections.heading: B. Contributions
sections.text: Key contributions to our work include: 1) We propose a multi-step end-to-end approach to the segmentation of anatomical organs in X-ray. 2) We propose a solution for training fully revolutionary models in the case of imbalanced representation of data. 3) We propose architectures that far exceed the most modern methods, especially in the task of collarbone segmentation in the publicly available JSRT dataset.

sections.heading: II. METHODOLOGY
sections.text: In this section, we begin with a formal description of the multi-class approach. We then briefly describe the basics on which our methods are based, and finally outline our architectural design strategies and propose a series of models that are suitable for solving the problems specific to CXR images.

sections.heading: D. Proposed Network Architectures
sections.text: We summarize the proposed architectures: • All-Dropout: Modified version of the U-Net architecture [28] with outage layers that are placed after each revolutionary layer. • InvertedNet: Similar to All-Dropout: Similar to All-Dropout with delayed subsampling of the first pooling layer and number of feature cards on the network that are inverted in relation to the original U-Net. • All-Dropout: Similar to All-Dropout with pooling layers that are replaced by new revolutionary layers, with filter sizes that correspond to the pooling size of the corresponding pooling layer. sections.heading: A. JSRT dataset
sections.text: We use the JSRT dataset [5] for both training and testing. The dataset consists of 247 x-rays of the posterior anterior (PA) chest with a resolution of 2048 x 2048, a pixel size of 0.175 mm and a depth of 12 bits. The reference organ boundaries for JSRT images for left and right lung fields, heart and left and right collarbones were introduced by van Ginneken et al. [6] in a resolution of 1024 x 1024 and are available in the SCR database.

sections.heading: B. Training Model
sections.text: The data were first normalized by subtracting the mean and then scaling using the standard deviation, and then divided into training and test sets. To make the paper comparable to images of one of the following resolutions, most of the results of our work correspond to the 256 x 256 image resolution. To optimize the model, we used the Adaptive Momentum Stimulation (ADAM) method [34], which uses an adaptive learning rate approach for each parameter, storing the decreasing average of the past two square gradients and past gradients. We varied different initial gradients to find the most stable convergence and 10 − 5 and 5 °, thus fixing the most reasonable 5 − 5 decisions, using the lower convergence compared to the latter.

sections.heading: B. Timing Performance
sections.text: Table II shows an overview of the proposed architectures with PC run times measured with Intel (R) Xeon (R) CPU E5-2650 v3 @ 2.30 GHz CPU and GeForce GTX TitanX GPU with 12 GB of memory. To the best of our knowledge, our method is currently the fastest segmentation approach for CXR images. With modern hardware, it can process thousands of images per day, which is particularly beneficial in large clinical environments where hundreds or sometimes thousands of people are checked daily.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we propose an end-to-end approach for multi-class segmentation of anatomical organs in CXR scans. We introduce and evaluate a total of three completely revolutionary architectures that achieve high test scores on public JSRT data sets that exhibit or exceed the original U-Net architecture and other state-of-the-art methods on all organs. Our best architecture outperforms the results of the human observer in the lungs and heart. Clavicle segmentation is still a challenging task for our architectures, even though they are much closer to the values of the human observer than any other state-of-the-art method before. Overall, results show that simply more regulation and the extraction of greater number of abstract features at a high level can be beneficial for improving the segmentation of smaller objects such as collarbones. Including weighting in the loss function is critical when dealing with the highly unbalanced data, which in CXR images is the case of smaller objects such as collarbones, where it exceeds the best function of 4.1%, with a loss of 8 times the original architecture, and nearly exceeds the best parameter of 8%.

metadata.abstractText: The recent success of Deep Convolutional Neural Networks on image classification and recognition tasks has led to new applications in very diversifying contexts. One of these is medical imaging where scarcity and imbalance of training data has hindered rapid development of neural network related applications. This paper investigates and proposes neural network architectures within the context of automated segmentation of anatomical organs in chest radiographs, namely for lung, clavicles and heart. By relating prior class data distributions to the objective function sparsely represented structures are methodologically emphasized. Scarce training sets and data augmentation are encountered with aggressive data regularization. The problem of highly imbalanced target object appearance in the input data is solved by modifying the objective function. The models are trained and tested on the publicly available JSRT database consisting of 247 X-Ray images the ground-truth masks for which available in the SCR database. The networks have been trained in a multi-class setup with three target classes. Our best performing model trained with the negative Dice loss function was able to reach mean Jaccard overlap scores of 94.1% for lungs, 86.6% for heart and 88.7% for clavicles in the multi-label setup, therefore, outperforming the best state-of-the art methods for heart and clavicle and human observer on lung and heart segmentation tasks.
